0: Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption Nick Bryant: Australian politics like "a soap opera directed by Tarantino" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard and the man she ousted, Kevin Rudd, are contesting a party leadership vote. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ms Gillard called the vote after Mr Rudd's supporters sought to force a party meeting to hold a ballot. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The vote was due to begin at 19:00 local time (09:00 GMT) on Wednesday. Both contenders have committed to stepping down if they lose. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The move comes ahead of a 14 September election, which polls suggest Labor is set to lose. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ms Gillard toppled Mr Rudd in a leadership challenge in 2010, but he remains more popular with voters. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Labor party has been divided by bitter in-fighting between supporters of Ms Gillard and Mr Rudd, and there has been sustained speculation over the leadership in recent weeks. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR If Mr Rudd replaces Ms Gillard as prime minister, he could be forced to call an early election. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 'This is it' NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Julia Gillard's call came hours after news surfaced that Kevin Rudd's supporters were circulating a petition calling for a caucus meeting to vote on the party leadership. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ms Gillard said that this was the final opportunity for the issue to be resolved. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I have been in a contest with the leader of the opposition, but I've also been in a political contest with people from my own political party," she said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We cannot have the government or the Labor Party go to the next election with a person leading the Labor Party and a person floating around as the potential alternate leader." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Timeline: Julia Gillard Dec 2006 : Appointed deputy leader of Labor Party NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : Appointed deputy leader of Labor Party Dec 2007 : Sworn in as deputy prime minister to PM Kevin Rudd NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : Sworn in as deputy prime minister to PM Kevin Rudd Jun 2010 : Successfully challenges Mr Rudd for the leadership, becomes 27th prime minister of Australia NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : Successfully challenges Mr Rudd for the leadership, becomes 27th prime minister of Australia Aug 2010 : General election results in hung parliament; forms minority government with independents NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : General election results in hung parliament; forms minority government with independents Feb 2012 : Survives a leadership challenge by Mr Rudd NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : Survives a leadership challenge by Mr Rudd Jan 2013 : Sets general election date of 14 September 2013 NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : Sets general election date of 14 September 2013 Mar 2013 : Leadership ballot called but Mr Rudd does not contest NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR : Leadership ballot called but Mr Rudd does not contest June 2013: Calls another leadership ballot after Mr Rudd's supporters attempt to force a vote Profile: Julia Gillard Profile: Kevin Rudd NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Anybody who enters the ballot tonight should do it on the following conditions: that if you win you're Labor leader, that if you lose you retire from politics." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This is it, tonight is the night," she said. "I wouldn't be putting myself forward unless I had a degree of confidence." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Shortly afterwards, Mr Rudd told reporters that he intended to run. "For the nation's sake I believe it's time for this matter to be resolved," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I believe with all my heart that I owe it to the Australian people to offer them a viable alternative." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He added that he believed the Labor party was "on course for a catastrophic defeat unless there is change". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "If I lose, of course I would announce that I would not contest the next election and I thank Julia for making the same commitment." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Rudd would need the support of at least 52 of Labor's 102 MPs in order to oust Ms Gillard. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In March Mr Rudd declined to contest a leadership vote and said afterwards that there were "no circumstances" under which he would seek the top job. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Nonetheless speculation that he could return had persisted amid polling showing he could deliver a better outcome for Labor in the election. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A poll published earlier this month suggested that three cabinet ministers would lose their seats under Ms Gillard, but would retain their seats if Mr Rudd was leading the party. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Tony Abbott leads the opposition coalition, which polls suggest is currently on course for a convincing win. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier on Wednesday, Tony Abbott challenged Ms Gillard to bring forward the election date to 3 August, and said that "paralysis" was gripping the government. it challenged Mr Julia Gillard's Labor's I
